questions.text: Which of the following site does the restriction enzyme act when RFLP is used in-order to identify the five different species of staphylococci in a surgical ICU? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GATATC- CTATAG

 

Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP) is a difference in homologous DNA sequences that can be detected by the presence of fragments of different lengths after digestion of the DNA samples in question with specific restriction endonucleases.

 

Restriction endonucleases have specific recognition sites where they cut the DNA. These enzymes recognize specific sequence with palindrome arrangement. These are also called inverted repeat sequences, which means the nucleotide sequence in 5′ to 3′ direction is the same in both strands.

 

Option B. is a palindromic sequence, hence the correct the answer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: ATGGAC – TACGTG 

 

  • This is not a palindrome.
  • 5'-ATGGAC
    3'-TACCTG 

 

Option C: TAGATA – ATCTAT 

 

  • Not a palindrome.
  • 5'-TAGATA
    3'-ATCTAT

 

Option D: AATATA – TATAAT 

 

  • 5'-AATATA
    3'-TATAAT
  • Not a palindrome either. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In RFLP, restriction enzymes recognize and cut at palindromic sequences in DNA. The palindromic sequence GATATC-CTATAG is a correct recognition site for these enzymes, making it crucial for identifying different species, such as staphylococci in a surgical ICU.

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is caused by the deficiency of? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lecithin

 

Specifically phosphatidylcholine, is a major component of pulmonary surfactant. Surfactant plays a crucial role in reducing surface tension in the alveoli of the lungs, preventing their collapse. A deficiency in lecithin can contribute to respiratory distress syndrome, especially in premature infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cephalin: Cephalin is a type of phospholipid, and while it is present in cell membranes, it is not a major component of pulmonary surfactant and is not directly associated with respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Option B. Sphingomyelin: Sphingomyelin is another type of phospholipid found in cell membranes. The deficiency to recycle this lipid due to defective lysosomal enzyme sphingomyelinase cause sphingolipidoses also known as Niemann Pick disease.

 

Option D. Cardiolipin: Cardiolipin is a phospholipid found in the inner mitochondrial membrane and bacterial membranes. The disease associated with cardiolipins are anti-phospholipid syndrome and Barth syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RDS is a common condition in premature infants due to inadequate surfactant production, particularly the deficiency of lecithin. The educational objective is to understand the etiology of RDS and its association with surfactant components, specifically lecithin. This knowledge is crucial for healthcare professionals involved in the care of neonates, as RDS can have serious respiratory consequences in premature infants and requires appropriate management and support.

questions.text: Which type of mutation results in the reversal to the wild type of phenotype when the mutant gene is suppressed? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mutation of tRNA

 

The correct answer is Mutation of tRNA. A suppressor mutation, specifically a tRNA mutation, can reverse the effect of an earlier mutation that produced a premature stop codon. In this scenario, the tRNA undergoes a mutation that allows it to recognize the stop codon (UAA in this case) as if it were a normal codon (e.g., serine's codon UCA). This suppressor tRNA can then insert an amino acid at the site of the stop codon, allowing protein synthesis to continue. This compensates for the earlier mutation that would have led to a truncated, non-functional protein, thereby restoring the wild-type phenotype.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frameshift mutation of coding gene: This type of mutation typically disrupts the reading frame of the gene, leading to widespread changes in the amino acid sequence from the point of mutation onward. It usually results in a non-functional protein and does not suppress the effects of another mutation.

 

Option B. Addition of another normal gene: While adding a normal gene might help correct a phenotype by introducing a functional version of the gene, it does not qualify as a suppressor mutation. This option does not specifically address the reversal of a mutation at the molecular level in the same way as tRNA mutation does.

 

Option C. Deletion of the mutant gene: Deleting the mutant gene would remove the mutation but would not revert the phenotype to wild type by itself. It eliminates the gene's effect entirely rather than compensating for the mutation within the gene or another gene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suppressor mutations, particularly those in tRNA, can reverse the effects of a previous mutation by allowing protein synthesis to continue even when a premature stop codon is present, thereby restoring the normal (wild-type) phenotype.

choices.text: Conversion of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA
Conversion of pyruvate to Lactic acid

questions.text: Identify the anaplerotic reaction among the following? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conversion of pyruvate to Oxaloacetate

 

Anaplerotic reactions are “filling up” reactions or “influx” reactions or “replenishing” reactions which supply 4-carbon units to the TCA cycle.

 

The important anaplerotic reactions are:

 

  1. Pyruvate to oxaloacetate by pyruvate carboxylase enzyme. It needs ATP.
  2. Glutamate is transaminated to alpha keto glutarate; and aspartate to oxaloacetate.
  3. Pyruvate can be carboxylated to malate by NADP+ dependent malic enzyme.

 

The citric acid cycle acts as a source of precursors of biosynthetic pathways, e.g., heme is synthesized from succinyl CoA and aspartate from oxaloacetate. To counterbalance such losses, and to keep the concentrations of the 4-carbon units in the cell, anaplerotic reactions are essential. This is called anaplerotic role of TCA cycle (Greek word, ana = up; plerotikos = to fill)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conversion of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA: This is not an anaplerotic reaction; it is a part of the link between glycolysis and the TCA cycle.

 

Option C. Conversion of pyruvate to Acetaldehyde: This reaction is part of ethanol fermentation, not an anaplerotic reaction.

 

Option D. Conversion of pyruvate to Lactic acid: This is part of anaerobic glycolysis (fermentation), not an anaplerotic reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaplerotic reactions, such as the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, are crucial for maintaining the levels of TCA cycle intermediates, enabling the cycle to function efficiently and support biosynthetic demands.

choices.text: Fatty acid synthesis

questions.text: A biochemistry student is studying the various roles of NADPH in cellular metabolism. The student learns that NADPH plays a critical role in providing reducing power for specific biosynthetic reactions. In which of the following biological processes is NADPH primarily utilized?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Fatty acid synthesis

 

Explanation:

 

NADPH is crucial in fatty acid synthesis, where it acts as a reducing agent that provides the necessary electrons to convert acetyl-CoA into long-chain fatty acids. NADPH donates hydrogen atoms during the reduction steps required to build carbon chains, particularly in the enzymatic actions of ketoacyl-ACP reductase and enoyl-ACP reductase during de novo fatty acid synthesis. The reducing power of NADPH is essential for the synthesis of fatty acids, as it helps convert precursors into fully formed fatty acid molecules.

 

Other Options:

 

A. DNA replication: DNA replication primarily involves the synthesis of DNA using nucleotides and enzymes such as DNA polymerase. NADPH does not play a direct role in this process, as the reactions are driven by nucleotide triphosphates rather than reduction.

 

C. Protein degradation: Protein degradation involves the breakdown of proteins into amino acids, mainly facilitated by proteolytic enzymes. This process does not require NADPH, as it involves hydrolysis rather than reduction.

 

D. Glycogenolysis: Glycogenolysis is the breakdown of glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate and glucose. This process is catalyzed by glycogen phosphorylase and other enzymes, and does not involve NADPH, as it is not a reducing process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NADPH is primarily used as a reducing agent in biosynthetic processes, such as fatty acid synthesis, cholesterol synthesis, and the detoxification of reactive oxygen species. It is generated by pathways like the hexose monophosphate shunt and utilized in reactions requiring reduction, underscoring its importance in cellular metabolism and protection against oxidative stress. Understanding NADPH's role in metabolic pathways highlights its critical function in anabolic and protective cellular processes.

questions.text: DNA packing is done by?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Histone

 

Histones are proteins responsible for DNA packaging. The DNA wraps around histones, forming a structure called a nucleosome. Histones are positively charged proteins that interact with the negatively charged DNA, allowing for efficient packaging and compaction of DNA strands. This packaging is essential for the organization of DNA within the cell nucleus and its regulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycoprotein: Glycoproteins are not directly involved in DNA packaging. They are molecules composed of a protein and a carbohydrate moiety. While glycoproteins have various functions in the cell, they do not play a role in the compaction and organization of DNA.

 

Option C. Nucleic acid: DNA itself is a type of nucleic acid. DNA molecules are composed of nucleotides and serve as the genetic material of cells. DNA molecules do not package themselves; instead, they interact with histones and other proteins to undergo packaging and compaction.

 

Option D. Helicases: Helicases are enzymes responsible for unwinding and separating the DNA strands during processes such as DNA replication and transcription. They do not participate in DNA packaging; instead, their role is to facilitate the access of various cellular machinery to the DNA template.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nucleosomes = DNA + Histone proteins

 

Histone proteins are rich in basic AA such as lysine and arginine, so, carry a positive charge. While DNA due to PO42- groups has large negative charge. So, in nucleosomes, DNA and histones are tightly packed due to interaction between these opposite charges.

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 351

questions.text: What is the order of drawing blood sample in vials/vacutainers: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Blue, Red, Lavender, Grey

 

Explanation:

 

Order of Draw in Blood Collection (Vacutainer Method)

 

The standard order of draw is important to avoid cross-contamination of additives between tubes, which can affect lab results.

 

Here’s the correct order based on CLSI (Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute) guidelines:

 

  1. Blood culture bottles (if needed)
  2. Light Blue – contains sodium citrate (for coagulation tests like PT, aPTT)
  3. Red / Gold / SST – no additive or clot activator (for serum tests)
  4. Green – contains heparin (for plasma chemistry)
  5. Lavender / Pink – contains EDTA (for hematology, e.g., CBC)
  6. Grey – contains sodium fluoride + potassium oxalate (for glucose and lactate)

 

So, the correct order of drawing blood samples in vials/vacutainers is Blue, Red, Lavender, Grey.

 

1. Blue: The blue-top tube is typically used for coagulation tests that require blood to be collected in citrate anticoagulant. The citrate in the tube helps prevent blood clotting by binding calcium.

 

2. Red: The red-top tube does not contain any anticoagulant and is commonly used for collecting blood samples for various tests, including serum chemistry, blood bank, and serology. After allowing the blood to clot, it is centrifuged, and the resulting serum is used for analysis.

 

3. Lavender: The lavender-top tube contains EDTA (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) as an anticoagulant. It is used for collecting whole blood for complete blood count (CBC), blood typing, and other hematological tests. EDTA helps preserve the blood cell morphology.

 

4. Grey: The grey-top tube contains an anticoagulant called potassium oxalate or sodium fluoride. It is used primarily for glucose testing and helps preserve blood glucose levels by inhibiting glycolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of drawing blood samples in vials/vacutainers is Blue (coagulation tests), Red (serum tests), Lavender (hematology tests), and Grey (glucose tests) to ensure accurate test results and avoid cross-contamination.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Muscle glycogen phosphorylase

 

The clinical features described are suggestive of McArdle's disease (glycogen storage disease type V), which is caused by a deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase. This enzyme deficiency leads to an inability to break down glycogen into glucose in the muscle cells, resulting in exercise intolerance, muscle pain, and accumulation of glycogen in muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle-debranching enzyme:

  • Deficiency: Causes Cori's disease (glycogen storage disease type III).
  • Clinical Features: Highly branched dextrin accumulates in liver and muscle, leading to fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and myopathy.
  • Note: This enzyme is involved in the debranching process of glycogenolysis, but the primary symptoms are different from those described in the question.

 

Option B. Phosphofructokinase 1:

  • Deficiency: Causes Tarui's disease (glycogen storage disease type VII).
  • Clinical Features: Exercise intolerance, muscle pain, and myoglobinuria, similar to McArdle's, but also includes hemolytic anemia due to the enzyme's role in glycolysis in red blood cells.
  • Note: This enzyme is involved in glycolysis, not directly in glycogen metabolism.

 

Option C. Glucose 6 phosphatase:

  • Deficiency: Causes Von Gierke's disease (glycogen storage disease type Ia).
  • Clinical Features: Fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, hyperuricemia, and lactic acidosis.
  • Note: This enzyme deficiency affects the liver's ability to release glucose, but not directly linked to muscle symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In which of the genetic material, Number of Adenine will not be equal to that of Thymine:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HIV

 

The questions is related to genetic material of different organisms or viruses and their base pairing rules. In DNA, adenine (A) always pairs with thymine (T), and cytosine (C) always pairs with guanine (G). However, in RNA, which is the genetic material of some viruses like HIV, thymine is replaced by uracil (U) in base pairing. So, in RNA, adenine pairs with uracil.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E. coli (Escherichia coli): E. coli is a bacterium, and its genetic material is DNA. In DNA, adenine pairs with thymine, so the number of adenine is equal to the number of thymine.

 

Option B. Mitochondrial DNA of humans: Mitochondrial DNA is also composed of DNA, and in DNA, adenine pairs with thymine. Therefore, the number of adenine is equal to the number of thymine.

 

Option D. Herpes virus: Herpes viruses have dsDNA as their genetic material, so adenine pairs with thymine in their DNA. Thus, the number of adenine is equal to the number of thymine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) is a retrovirus with RNA as its genetic material. In RNA, adenine pairs with uracil. So, the number of adenine will not be equal to that of thymine.

choices.text: Human cells can divide a finite number of times only
Free radical oxidation level is unrestricted
RNA polymerase can function for a finite number of times only

questions.text: What is true about the Hayflick limit? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Human cells can divide a finite number of times only

 

Leonard Hayflick discovered that cultured normal human cells have limited capacity to divide, after which they become senescent — a phenomenon now known as the ‘Hayflick limit’.

 

Each time a cell undergoes mitosis, the telomeres on the ends of each chromosome shorten slightly. Cell division will cease once telomeres shorten to a critical length. Hayflick interpreted his discovery to be aging at the cellular level. The aging of cell populations appears to correlate with the overall physical aging of an organism. Normal human fetal cell population will divide between 40 and 60 times in cell culture before entering a senescence phase. However, this limit does not apply to stem cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Free radical oxidation level is unrestricted: Free radical oxidation is related to oxidative stress and damage but is not directly related to the Hayflick limit.

 

Option C. Telomerase activity is unrestricted: In most somatic cells, telomerase activity is limited, leading to telomere shortening. However, certain cells like stem cells and cancer cells exhibit higher telomerase activity, allowing them to bypass the Hayflick limit.

 

Option D. RNA polymerase can function for a finite number of times only: RNA polymerase activity is not directly linked to the Hayflick limit and does not have a finite number of times it can function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hayflick limit describes the finite number of times that normal human cells can divide before they become senescent, primarily due to telomere shortening.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases have autosomal recessive inheritance? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Albinism

 

Albinism is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. To have albinism, an individual must inherit two copies of the mutated gene for albinism, one from each parent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. G-6-PD deficiency: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G-6-PD) deficiency is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner, not autosomal recessive. It affects males more often than females.

 

Option C. Marfan's syndrome: Marfan's syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, not autosomal recessive. A single copy of the mutated gene from one parent is enough to cause the condition.

 

Option D. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner. It primarily affects males who inherit the mutated gene from their carrier mothers.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In MSUD (Maple Syrup Urine disorder) which of the following is not restricted:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methionine

 

  • Methionine is not restricted in MSUD. MSUD is characterized by the inability to break down three specific branched-chain amino acids: Leucine, Isoleucine, and Valine. Methionine is not one of the amino acids that are restricted in the diet of individuals with MSUD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valine: Valine is one of the amino acids restricted in MSUD. People with MSUD need to limit their intake of Valine as their bodies cannot properly metabolize it.

 

Option C. Leucine: Leucine is another amino acid that is restricted in MSUD. It is one of the three branched-chain amino acids that individuals with MSUD need to limit in their diet.

 

Option D. Isoleucine: Isoleucine is also restricted in MSUD. Like Valine and Leucine, Isoleucine is a branched-chain amino acid that individuals with MSUD need to restrict to manage the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched Chain Keto-acid Decarboxylase resulting in defect in oxidative decarboxylation and catabolism of branched chain amino acids Valine, Isoleucine and leucine. As a result, these amino acids accumulate and are excreted in urine. So, for the treatment, these BCAA should be restricted in diet.

 

Methionine is a sulphur containing amino acid and do not require this enzyme for its metabolism. So, its restriction is not required in MSUD.  

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 290

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is based on RNA? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RT-PCR

 

RT PCR is RNA-based technique.

 

It is the method used to amplify, isolate or identify a known sequence from a cell or tissue RNA library. Essentially normal PCR is preceded by reverse transcription (to convert the RNA to cDNA). This is widely used in expression mapping, determining when and where certain genes are expressed. Tth polymerase from Thermus thermophilus may be used. This enzyme has both DNA polymerase and reverse transcriptase activities at high temperature. This allows both cDNA synthesis from mRNA followed by PCR amplification.

In ordinary PCR, DNA is detected; that DNA could be from a living or non-living organism. But in reverse PCR, mRNA is detected; that means, it is derived from a living organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sanger's technique - Sanger sequencing, also known as the “chain termination method”, is a method for determining the nucleotide sequence of DNA.

 

Option C. Next-generation DNA sequencing technologies also called deep sequencing, is a technology that enables parallel multiplexed analysis of DNA sequences on a massive scale.

 

Option D. Western blot is used to detect specific protein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RT-PCR is an RNA-based technique that involves reverse transcription of RNA into cDNA followed by PCR amplification, widely used in gene expression analysis.

questions.text: Which of the following tissues are dependent on insulin for glucose uptake? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Muscle and adipose tissues

 

Explanation:

 

GLUT-4 glucose transporter is insulin dependent and is the only GLUT present in muscle and adipose tissues. So, muscles and adipose tissues are totally dependent on Insulin for glucose uptake.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver: The liver uses GLUT-2 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. GLUT-2 allows the liver to take up glucose and store it as glycogen or use it for energy production, independent of insulin.

 

Option B. Pancreas: The pancreas also uses GLUT-2 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. In the pancreas, GLUT-2 plays a role in sensing blood glucose levels and regulating insulin secretion.

 

Option D. Placenta: The placenta uses GLUT-1 and GLUT-3 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. These transporters facilitate the basal uptake of glucose to support the energy needs of the placenta and fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old researcher is studying various amino acids and their incorporation into proteins during post-translational modifications. During a discussion on how certain amino acids are synthesized and integrated into proteins, he comes across an amino acid that is incorporated directly during translation rather than being formed through post-translational modification. Which of the following amino acids is not produced through post-translational modification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Selenocysteine

 

Explanation:

 

Selenocysteine, often referred to as the 21st amino acid, is unique because it is directly incorporated into proteins during translation, rather than being formed through post-translational modification. It is encoded by the UGA codon, which usually signals a stop but is recoded to incorporate selenocysteine due to the presence of a specific secondary structure in the mRNA called the Selenocysteine Insertion Sequence (SECIS). The synthesis of selenocysteine involves replacing the oxygen of serine with selenium. It plays a crucial role in the active sites of several enzymes, such as thioredoxin reductase, glutathione peroxidase, and deiodinases, which are important for antioxidant defense and thyroid hormone metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

A. N-formylmethionine: N-formylmethionine is a modified form of methionine that serves as the initiator amino acid in bacterial protein synthesis. It is a result of a post-translational modification that adds a formyl group to methionine, unlike selenocysteine which is directly incorporated during translation.

 

C. γ-Carboxyglutamate: This modified form of glutamate is generated through post-translational carboxylation, which is essential in blood clotting factors to bind calcium ions, a key step in the coagulation cascade.

 

D. Phosphoserine: Phosphoserine is formed by the phosphorylation of serine residues in proteins, a common post-translational modification that plays a significant role in regulating protein function, unlike selenocysteine which is directly integrated during protein synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selenocysteine is distinct among amino acids as it is incorporated during translation rather than being modified post-translationally. This unique incorporation mechanism highlights its specialized role in the active sites of specific enzymes, emphasizing the critical nature of direct incorporation for its biological functions.

questions.text: A patient who is a diagnosed case of HNPCC, which of the following is the most common repair associated with it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mismatch repair

 

Explanation:

 

Mismatch Repair (MMR) defect leads to Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC). This mechanism corrects errors that typically occur during DNA replication. Mutations in MMR genes result in microsatellite instability and contribute to the development of various cancers at an early age. In contrast, Homologous Repair (HR) defects are associated with other genetic disorders and cancers, including Bloom syndrome, Werner syndrome, breast cancer, and Ataxia-Telangiectasia like disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nucleotide excision repair: Incorrect for this context as it deals with the repair of bulky helix-distorting lesions caused by UV radiation and chemicals, leading to diseases like Xeroderma pigmentosum.

 

Option C. Base excision repair: Incorrect as it fixes small non-helix-distorting bases caused by spontaneous or induced changes, leading to conditions like MUTYH-associated polyposis when defective.

 

Option D. Homologous recombinant repair: Incorrect for HNPCC. It repairs double-strand breaks or interstrand cross-links in DNA, not typically involved in the pathogenesis of HNPCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/pg. 370

questions.text: Methyl tetrahydrofolate accumulation and functional deficiency of folate is seen in the deficiency of: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vit B12

 

Vitamin B12, also known as cobalamin, is essential for DNA synthesis and plays a role in the conversion of methyl tetrahydrofolate to its active form. Deficiency of vitamin B12 can lead to the functional deficiency of folate because it impairs the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from methyl tetrahydrofolate, leading to the accumulation of the latter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folic acid: Folic acid, also known as vitamin B9, is a crucial vitamin required for DNA synthesis, cell division, and various metabolic processes. In cases of folic acid deficiency, methyl tetrahydrofolate can accumulate, but there is no direct deficiency of vitamin B12. Folic acid deficiency primarily affects folate-dependent reactions.

 

Option C. Vit B1: Vitamin B1, also known as thiamine, is not directly related to the metabolism of folate or methyl tetrahydrofolate. It primarily plays a role in carbohydrate metabolism as a cofactor for enzymes involved in the citric acid cycle.

 

Option D. Vit B6: Vitamin B6, also known as pyridoxine, is involved in various enzymatic reactions, including those related to amino acid metabolism. It is not directly associated with the metabolism of folate or methyl tetrahydrofolate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the metabolic consequences of vitamin deficiencies, medical students should recognize that the functional deficiency of folate, characterized by the accumulation of methyl tetrahydrofolate, is primarily seen in vitamin B12 deficiency, making it important to distinguish between the two deficiencies in clinical practice.

 

Deficiency of Vitamin B12 leads to accumulation of methyl THF. Free THF becomes deficient (Folate Trap) and as THF is functional form of folate it is also known as functional deficiency of folate.

 

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 536

questions.text: Chimeric DNA is used for? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Organ transplantation

 

Chimeric DNA (also known a recombinant DNA) is used in organ transplantation, especially in bone marrow transplant. It allows for the production of essential therapeutic proteins and other biological products.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paternity test:

  • Function: Uses genetic markers to determine biological parentage.
  • Relevance: Typically uses DNA fingerprinting rather than chimeric DNA technology.

 

Option B. Maternity test:

  • Function: Similar to paternity testing, using genetic markers for parentage.
  • Relevance: Uses DNA fingerprinting, not chimeric DNA.

 

Option C. Personal identification:

  • Function: Uses DNA profiling for forensic and legal identification.
  • Relevance: DNA fingerprinting and STR analysis are common methods, not chimeric DNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uses of Chimeric DNA are:

 

  1. Recombinant human insulin
  2. Recombinant human growth hormone (HGH, somatotropin) and other human hormones (e.g. FSH)
  3. Recombinant blood clotting factor VIII and other clotting factors (Factor IX, tPA, hirudin)
  4. Recombinant hepatitis B vaccine, HPV vaccine, etc.
  5. Cytokines and growth factors (interferon, interleukins, etc.)
  6. Monoclonal antibodies and other related products (rituximab, trastuzumab, etc.)
  7. Recombinant enzymes (acid α glucosidase [myozyme], α L iduronidase [aldurazyme])
  8. Recombinant HIV protein for HIV ELISA testing
  9. Herbicide and insect resistant crops
  10. Other products: Bone morphogenic protein (BMP), albumin, fibinolytic and thrombolytic agents, etc.
  11. Gene mapping using techniques such as fluorescence in sit hybridization (FISH).
  12. Molecular analysis of disease, to detect gene variations and mutations.
  13. Restriction Fragment Length polymorphism (RFLP) and single nucleotide polymorphism (SN)
  14. Microsatellite DNA polymorphisms
  15. Gene therapy and bone marrow transplantation

questions.text: Which of the following is not an amphipathic Lipid? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triglycerides

 

  • Triglycerides are not amphipathic lipids. They consist of three fatty acid chains esterified to a glycerol molecule. These molecules are hydrophobic and do not have a polar or hydrophilic region. Triglycerides are the primary storage form of energy in the body and are commonly found in adipose tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphoglycerol: Phosphoglycerol, also known as phosphoglyceride or glycerophospholipid, is an amphipathic lipid. It has a polar phosphate head group and two hydrophobic fatty acid tails. Phosphoglycerides are essential components of cell membranes, where they form the lipid bilayer.

 

Option C. Glycolipids: Glycolipids are amphipathic lipids. They have a hydrophilic carbohydrate (sugar) head group and hydrophobic lipid tails. Glycolipids are important in cell membranes, particularly in nerve cells and the myelin sheath. They play a role in cell signaling and recognition.

 

Option D. Sphingolipids: Sphingolipids are amphipathic lipids. They consist of a sphingosine backbone, a hydrophilic head group (usually containing a sugar), and one or two hydrophobic fatty acid tails. Sphingolipids are crucial components of cell membranes and are involved in various cellular processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triglycerides are not amphipathic lipids, while phosphoglycerol, glycolipids, and sphingolipids are amphipathic and play important roles in cell membrane structure and function.

 

They are formed by esterification between three Fatty acids and one glycerol molecule. As Ester bond is non-polar so, molecule of TG is a non-polar. They are also called as neutral fats.

questions.text: Which of the following has protective as well as lubricating property? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucin

 

Mucins form a protective barrier on epithelial surfaces. They are also found in secretions of the gastrointestinal, respiratory and urogenital tract. They also have lubricating properties.

 

Functions of Mucin:

  1. Membrane-bound mucins participate in various cell-cell interactions.
  2. Protective barrier on epithelial surfaces.
  3. Lubricating properties.
  4. "Mask" certain surface antigens.
  5. Mucins also carry cancer-specific peptide and carbohydrate epitopes.

 

Salient features of Mucin:

  1. Found in secretions of the gastrointestinal, respiratory, and reproductive tracts and also in membranes of various cells.
  2. Exhibit high content of O-glycan chains, usually containing NeuAc.
  3. Contain repeating amino acid sequences rich in serine, threonine, and proline.
  4. Extended structure contributes to their high viscoelasticity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collagen: Collagen provides structural support and strength to tissues but does not have significant lubricating properties.

 

Option C. Albumin: Albumin is a major plasma protein involved in maintaining osmotic pressure and transporting various substances but does not have lubricating properties.

 

Option D. Immunoglobulin: Immunoglobulins are antibodies that play a crucial role in immune response but do not provide lubrication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucins have both protective and lubricating properties, forming a barrier on epithelial surfaces and reducing friction in various body tracts. They are essential for maintaining the integrity and function of mucosal surfaces.

questions.text: The illustration below shows alternative splicing of a gene which has intron segments 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. It yields two products A and B, by the action of different promoters. You are provided with the promoters W, X, Y, and Z, each of which binds to a different segment as shown below and acts in the marked direction. Which of the following promoters will you use to get product A? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. W Y

 

Explanation:

 

A promoter is a region of DNA upstream of a gene where relevant proteins bind to initiate

transcription of that gene. In the case of this question, product A is formed by including specific

segments and excluding others through the process of alternative splicing.

 

  • Sequence A consists of segments 1, 3, 4, and 5.
    • Promoter W Required for segment 1.
    • Promoter Y Required for segments 3, 4, and 5.
    • Segment 2 is excluded during alternative splicing.

 

Thus, the combination of Promoters W and Y will result in the production of sequence A by including

the correct segments and excluding segment 2.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a (W, X, Y): This combination Required Promoter X, for segment 2, but it

    is unnecessary since W and Y alone are sufficient to yield product A.

  • Option b (W, Z): Promoter Z does not include segments 3, making this option incorrect for generating product A.
  • Option c (WX): Promoters W and X are insufficient because they do not include segments 3, 4, and 5, which are essential for product A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A promoter is a region of DNA upstream of a gene where relevant proteins bind to initiate

transcription of that gene.

 

Using promoters W, Y will yield product A by including segments 1, 3, 4, and 5 and removing segment 2 through alternative splicing.

questions.text: What is the primary role of CG islands in our DNA? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Methylation

 

Explanation

 

CG islands, also known as CpG islands, are regions rich in cytosine and guanine dinucleotides in which the cytosine residues can be methylated. This methylation process plays a crucial role in regulating gene expression by affecting the accessibility of DNA to transcription machinery, thereby influencing whether genes are active or silenced.

 

Other Options

 

  • b. Acetylation: Incorrect because acetylation typically involves histones, not directly the DNA or specific DNA regions like CG islands.
  • c. t-RNA synthesis: Incorrect as t-RNA synthesis is not directly related to CG islands; it generally occurs in the nucleolus and involves RNA polymerase III.
  • d. DNA replication: Incorrect because, while CG islands may influence the overall structure and replication timing of the genome, they are not directly involved in the replication process itself.

 

Educational Objective

 

CG islands are crucial for the methylation of DNA, a key epigenetic mechanism that regulates gene expression without altering the DNA sequence itself.

questions.text: What is the function of the proteasome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Protein degradation

 

The primary function of the proteasome is to degrade intracellular proteins. It plays a crucial role in maintaining cellular homeostasis by breaking down unneeded or damaged proteins. Proteins are targeted for degradation by being tagged with a small protein called ubiquitin, and the proteasome then recognizes and degrades these ubiquitinated proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protein folding: The proteasome is not involved in protein folding. Protein folding is a process where newly synthesized proteins attain their three-dimensional, functional structures. It typically occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and is assisted by chaperone proteins.

 

Option B. Post-translational modification: While some post-translational modifications of proteins can occur in the proteasome, its primary function is not post-translational modification. Post-translational modifications include processes like phosphorylation, glycosylation, and ubiquitination, which may occur on proteins both before and after they enter the proteasome.

 

Option D. Protein sorting: Protein sorting involves directing proteins to their correct cellular locations, such as organelles like the mitochondria or lysosomes. The proteasome's main function is not related to protein sorting but rather protein degradation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ubiquitin tagged proteins are immediately broken down inside the proteasomes of the cells. The proteasome assembly has a central cylindrical hollow core. Ubiquitin-tagged proteins are taken into this barrel, and surrounding proteolytic enzymes digest the protein into small oligopeptides of 5-6 amino acids length

 

The proteasome is a cylindrical structure in the cytosol that degrades polyubiquitinated proteins. It has a central core with proteolytic enzymes. Proteins that are tagged by ubiquitin to be degraded enter the core through regulatory rings on either side of the cylinder.    

 

It plays the major role in the degradation of proteins, and is particularly associated with disposal of misfolded proteins and regulatory enzymes that have short half-lives.

questions.text: 2,3 BPG binds to: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Globin part of Hb

 

2,3-BPG binds to the globin part of hemoglobin. The binding of 2,3-BPG reduces the oxygen affinity of hemoglobin, promoting the release of oxygen in tissues where it is needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This option is not accurate. 2,3-BPG does not directly bind to the heme group of hemoglobin. Instead, it interacts with the globin chains of hemoglobin.

 

Option C. Haem part of Myoglobin:

  • This option is not accurate. Myoglobin is a single-chain protein, and it does not contain heme groups like hemoglobin. Myoglobin directly binds oxygen to store it in muscle tissues, but it does not interact with 2,3-BPG.

 

Option D. Globin part of Myoglobin:

  • This option is not accurate. Myoglobin is a single-chain protein, and it does not contain globin chains like hemoglobin. Myoglobin directly binds oxygen in muscle tissues but does not interact with 2,3-BPG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

2,3 BPG has negative charge whereas beta chain of hemoglobin has large positive charges due to amino acids His and Lys. Together they form the salt bridges (see fig) which promote formation of taut conformation and helps in deoxygenation.

questions.text: Glycogen phosphorylase is activated by? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium

 

  • Glycogen phosphorylase is primarily activated indirectly by calcium ions. An increase in intracellular calcium levels triggers the activation of phosphorylase kinase, which, in turn, activates glycogen phosphorylase. Calcium acts as a secondary messenger to stimulate this cascade of enzymatic reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose 6 Phosphate: Glucose 6-phosphate, a product of glycogenolysis (glycogen breakdown), actually inhibits glycogen phosphorylase. It is part of a negative feedback mechanism to prevent excessive glycogen breakdown when glucose levels are sufficient.

 

Option C. Insulin: Insulin does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. Instead, insulin plays a role in promoting glycogen synthesis by activating glycogen synthase and inhibiting glycogen phosphorylase.

 

 

Option D. Glucose: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose signal that glucose is available for energy production, leading to the inhibition of glycogenolysis and glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen phosphorylase is activated indirectly through the calcium signaling pathway, which initiates a series of enzymatic reactions ultimately leading to the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. This mechanism allows the regulation of glycogen breakdown in response to cellular energy needs.

questions.text: A diagram illustrating the natural history of a disease has points marked A, B, C, and D. Which point indicates the onset of symptoms in the disease's natural history? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Point C

 

Point C: Marks onset of clinical signs and symptoms

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Point A: Entry of infectious agent into the host.

 

Option B. Point B: Pathological and physiological changes occur in the stage of the subclinical phase. These changes are induced by the causative agent but are not sufficient enough to cause clinical signs and symptoms.

 

Option D. Point D: Usual time of diagnosis at which clinical signs and symptoms are well evident.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presents in emergency department with sudden hematemesis. He has been taking aspirin for his arthritis and drinks alcohol occasionally. He gives a history of occasional abdominal pain. On examination, there is no abdominal mass or tenderness. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peptic ulcer

 

  • This patient most likely has a bleeding peptic ulcer.
  •  Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) includes both gastric and duodenal ulcers.
  •  Aspirin, an NSAID, interferes with the protective role of prostaglandins on the gastric and duodenal mucosa, increasing the risk of peptic ulcer formation in the stomach and the duodenum.
  •  Common presentations of peptic ulcers include pain in the epigastrium, bleeding, and vomiting.
  • The history of aspirin use and alcohol consumption further supports the diagnosis of a peptic ulcer.

 

Peptic Ulcer Disease (PUD)

 

  • Etiology: Helicobacter pylori infection and NSAID use.
  • Mechanism: NSAIDs like aspirin disrupt the protective mucosal layer, leading to ulcer formation.
  • Symptoms: Epigastric pain, hematemesis, melena.
  • Sequelae:
    • Bleeding (more common in duodenal ulcers)
    • Perforation leading to peritonitis
    • Stricture causing gastric outlet obstruction
    • Malignancy risk (only in gastric ulcers)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mallory-Weiss:

 

  • Occurs following repeated vomiting or retching, often associated with an alcoholic binge.
  • Characterized by mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Presents with self-limiting hematemesis, not usually profuse.

 

Option B. Esophagitis:

 

  • Inflammation of the esophagus, often due to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • Results in chronic blood loss and commonly presents as anemia rather than sudden hematemesis.
  • Symptoms include heartburn, regurgitation, and dysphagia.

 

Option D. Esophageal varices:

 

  • Dilated submucosal veins in the lower esophagus, often due to portal hypertension.
  • Common in patients with liver cirrhosis.
  • Presents with massive hematemesis, splenomegaly, and ascites, none of which are described in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is a common cause of sudden hematemesis, especially in patients with risk factors such as NSAID use (e.g., aspirin) and occasional alcohol consumption.
  • Recognition of these risk factors is crucial in diagnosing and managing PUD effectively.

questions.text: All of the following drugs act as HER-1 inhibitors except (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pertuzumab

 

  • Pertuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets HER-2 (Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2), not HER-1. 
  • It is used primarily in the treatment of HER-2 positive breast cancer.
  • HER-1 (Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 1) is also known as EGFR (Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor). 
  • Several monoclonal antibodies target EGFR, while others target different members of the HER family, such as HER-2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cetuximab: Cetuximab is an EGFR (HER-1) inhibitor used primarily in the treatment of certain types of colorectal cancer and head and neck cancer.

 

Option B. Necitumumab: Necitumumab is also an EGFR (HER-1) inhibitor, used in the treatment of metastatic squamous non-small cell lung cancer.

 

Option D. Panitumumab: Panitumumab is an EGFR (HER-1) inhibitor, used in the treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer.

 

Given this information, the drug that does not act as a HER-1 inhibitor is: 
c. Pertuzumab

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in image below? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Congenital melanocytic nevus

 

The Picture shown above depicts a child with a well circumscribed, black, heterogenous lesion covered with hair. This is a characteristic lesion of congenital melanocytic nevus (CMN).

 

CMNs are benign proliferations of nevus cells that are present at birth or develop shortly after. They are known for their variable pigmentation and the presence of terminal hair.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermal verrucous nevus:

 

  • Description: A type of epidermal nevus (skin lesion) that is characterized by a warty or rough appearance as seen in the below image.

 

 

  • Why it's not the answer: While these can be present at birth or appear later in life, they don't typically present as deeply pigmented lesions with dense hair.

 

Option C. Melanoacanthoma:

 

  • Description: A rare, benign skin lesion that typically presents as a rapidly growing, hyperpigmented patch or plaque as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • It has a combination of melanocytes and keratinocytes.
  • Why it's not the answer: Although melanoacanthomas are pigmented lesions, they don't typically have dense hair growth, making it less consistent with the provided description.

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma:

 

  • Description: A type of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes. It can appear as a new, irregularly-shaped mole with uneven color or a mole that changes in size, shape, or color.
  • Why it's not the answer: While malignant melanoma is a pigmented lesion, the hallmark features include asymmetry, border irregularity, color variation, and diameter enlargement (often referred to by the mnemonic ABCD) as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • The presence of dense hair is not a characteristic feature of melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Melanocytic Nevus (CMN):

 

  • Presentation: These nevi are typically pigmented and hairy and may vary in size. The presence of hair is a distinguishing feature that often helps differentiate them from other pigmented lesions.
  • Risk Factors: Larger nevi have a higher risk of developing malignant melanoma later in life, but this is rare with smaller nevi.
  • Management: Monitoring is essential, and in some cases, surgical removal may be considered for aesthetic reasons or to reduce melanoma risk, particularly in larger lesions.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 75 Page no 75.14

questions.text: Match the characteristics resulting from the compression of the listed structures in the event of thyroid enlargement. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a

 

Explanation

 

  1. Trachea - c. Dyspnea (Difficulty Breathing): Thyroid enlargement can lead to the compression of the trachea (windpipe), causing narrowing of the airway. This compression can result in difficulty breathing, also known as dyspnea.
  2. Esophagus - d. Dysphagia (Difficulty Swallowing): When the thyroid gland enlarges and presses against the esophagus (the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach), it can interfere with the normal swallowing process, leading to dysphagia or difficulty swallowing.
  3. Sympathetic Chain - b. Horner's Syndrome: Compression of the sympathetic chain, which runs along the sides of the neck, can result in Horner's syndrome. Horner's syndrome includes signs such as ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on one side of the face. Thyroid enlargement can affect sympathetic nerve fibers and lead to these symptoms.
  4. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve - a. Hoarseness: The recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates the muscles responsible for vocal cord movement. Compression or damage to this nerve due to thyroid enlargement can result in hoarseness of voice and voice changes.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Fluoroacetate is a component of pesticides. Which of the following metabolic pathways is inhibited by this compound? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TCA cycle

 

Sodium fluoroacetate, is usually used as a rodenticide. It is highly toxic towards humans and other mammals through inhibition of the enzyme aconitase in the tricarboxylic acid cycle (metabolic uncoupler), caused by 'lethal synthesis' of an isomer of fluorocitrate (FC). FA is found in a range of plant species and their ingestion can cause the death of ruminant animals.

 

Inhibition of the TCA Cycle by Fluoroacetate:

  • Aconitase: Converts citrate to aconitate.
  • Inhibition: Fluoroacetate is metabolized to fluorocitrate, which inhibits aconitase, leading to the accumulation of citrate and disruption of the TCA cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycolytic pathway:

  • Function: Converts glucose to pyruvate, generating ATP.
  • Inhibition: Fluoroacetate does not affect glycolysis.

 

Option C. Oxidative phosphorylation:

  • Function: Produces ATP through the electron transport chain and ATP synthase.
  • Inhibition: Fluoroacetate does not directly inhibit oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Option D. ETC (Electron Transport Chain):

  • Function: Transfers electrons from NADH and FADH2 to oxygen, generating ATP.
  • Inhibition: Fluoroacetate does not directly inhibit the electron transport chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibitors of TCA Cycle

choices.text: Endodermal sinus tumor
Malignant teratoma
Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma

questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient presents with an ovarian mass. On further evaluation, her serum biomarkers are found to be normal except for LDH, which is found to be elevated. The most likely diagnosis is: (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dysgerminoma

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical history of a 16-year-old female presenting with an ovarian mass with raised LDH points towards the diagnosis of dysgerminoma. Dysgerminomas usually arise in young women or in children, with an average incidence at the age of 20. They currently account for approximately one-third of all malignant ovarian germ cell tumors and are the most common malignant ovarian tumors found in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endodermal sinus tumor: This is typically associated with elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), not LDH.

 

Option C. Malignant teratoma: This type of tumor does not typically present with elevated LDH as the sole abnormal marker.

 

Option D. Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma: This epithelial ovarian tumor is usually associated with elevated CA-125, not LDH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dysgerminoma is the most likely diagnosis in a young female with an ovarian mass and elevated LDH levels.

 

Ref: Page no 381, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: How is ammonia removed from the brain? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: D. Glutamine

 

Explanation:

 

In the brain, ammonia is detoxified by being converted into glutamine through the enzyme glutamine synthetase. This process combines glutamate with ammonia, safely encapsulating the ammonia for transport to the liver, where it can be further processed.  

 

Other options:

 

  • Urea: Ammonia is not directly converted into urea in the brain; rather, it is converted into glutamine, which is transported to the liver where urea synthesis occurs.
  • Alanine: While alanine does act as a carrier of ammonia in muscles by transamination reactions, it is not a primary pathway for ammonia removal in the brain.
  • Glutamate: Although glutamate is involved in the initial steps, it is the substrate that accepts ammonia to form glutamine, not the final carrier of ammonia.

 

Educational Objective

 

Glutamine acts as a non-toxic carrier of ammonia from the brain to the liver, where ammonia is further processed into urea, showcasing the brain's indirect participation in the urea cycle.

questions.text: Grievous hurt under Section 320 IPC include all except: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 7 days admission in hospital

 

The duration of hospital stay alone does not define grievous hurt under IPC 320. The nature and severity of the injury are the determining factors, not the length of hospitalization.

 

Other Options:

 

Grievous hurt under Section 320 IPC:

 

Option A. Permanent privation of hearing: This is considered grievous hurt as it results in the permanent loss of a sense, causing significant and lasting disability.

 

Option B. Fracture femur: Fracture of the femur is explicitly mentioned under IPC 320 as grievous hurt due to the severity and potential long-term consequences of the injury.

 

Option D. Emasculation: This involves depriving a man of his masculine vigour and is considered grievous hurt due to the significant physical and psychological impact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grievous hurt under IPC 320 involves injuries that cause permanent disability, severe bodily pain, or life-altering effects. Hospital stay duration alone does not qualify an injury as grievous hurt unless accompanied by a severe or specified injury under the law.

choices.text: BP > 160/90 mmHg with one anti-hypertensive
BP > 140/90 mmHg with one anti-hypertensive
BP > 140/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives
BP > 160/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives

questions.text: Resistant hypertension is defined as? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) BP > 140/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives.

 

Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure that remains above goal despite the concurrent use of three anti-hypertensive agents of different classes. Typically, one of the three medications should be a diuretic, and all agents should be prescribed at optimal dose amounts. The threshold set for defining resistant hypertension is blood pressure greater than 140/90 mmHg.

 

Resistant hypertension indicates a situation where blood pressure control is inadequate despite the use of multiple medications, which can pose significant risks for cardiovascular complications and requires careful evaluation for secondary causes. This includes assessing for white-coat HTN/Pseudo HTN, medication adherence, lifestyle factors, and secondary causes of hypertension like renal artery stenosis, endocrine disorders, or medication-induced hypertension.

 

Home BP monitoring, ABPM (Ambulatory BP monitoring) can help in optimization of drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Resistant HTN refers to BP > 140/90 mmHg despite three anti-HTN, one being a diuretic.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Cardiology/Hypertensive Disease/ chap 277

questions.text: Which of the following murmur increases on standing? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. HOCM

 

The murmur of Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM) typically increases on standing. This is due to the decreased venous return and preload that occur with standing, which result in a reduction in the size of the left ventricular cavity. The smaller cavity size exacerbates the outflow obstruction under the aortic valve, thereby intensifying the murmur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral Regurgitation (MR): The murmur associated with MR typically decreases when standing due to the decreased venous return and reduced volume load on the left ventricle, which lessens the regurgitant flow across the mitral valve.

 

Option C. Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD): The murmur of a VSD generally decreases on standing due to reduced left to right shunting caused by decreased venous return.

 

Option D. Mitral Stenosis (MS): The murmur of mitral stenosis also decreases on standing. The reduction in preload lessens the flow through the narrowed mitral valve, subsequently reducing the intensity of the murmur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the options listed, the murmur of Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy is unique in that it increases on standing, due to the specific hemodynamic changes that accentuate the outflow obstruction. This characteristic can be a crucial diagnostic clue in the clinical assessment of murmurs.

 

Reference - Harrison/Physical examination of CVS/Chap 239

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used for typhoid fever in adults? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amikacin

 

Amikacin is not used in the treatment of typhoid fever as it is ineffective in clinical infections.

 

Amikacin is an aminoglycoside. Despite showing efficient in vitro killing of Salmonella, first- and second-generation cephalosporins, and aminoglycosides have proven to be ineffective in actual clinical cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azithromycin: This macrolide antibiotic is commonly used for treating typhoid fever, especially in cases where fluoroquinolone resistance is present.

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin: A fluoroquinolone antibiotic, it has been a standard treatment for typhoid fever, though resistance to this class is increasing.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: This third-generation cephalosporin is used to treat typhoid fever, particularly in cases of multidrug-resistant Salmonella typhi.

 

Educational Objective:


Amikacin is not effective in the treatment of typhoid fever, despite its efficacy in vitro against Salmonella.

questions.text: Pacinian corpuscle is stimulated by which of the following? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pressure

 

Pacinian corpuscle is stimulated by pressure.

 

  • Pacinian corpuscles (Vater-Pacini or lamellar corpuscles) are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptors for vibration and deep pressure and are essential for proprioception.
  • They can be found throughout the whole body; however, it is the hands and feet where they occur most numerously and tightly grouped.
  • They are composed of a nerve ending which is encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue that give it an onion-like appearance and are present in the dermis. The sensory nerves from cutaneous mechanoreceptors are myelinated Aα and Aβ fibers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pain: Incorrect. Pain is detected by nociceptors, not Pacinian corpuscles.

 

Option B. Temperature: Incorrect. Temperature is detected by thermoreceptors, not Pacinian corpuscles.

 

Option C. Touch: Incorrect. Touch is detected by various mechanoreceptors, including Meissner's corpuscles and Merkel discs, but Pacinian corpuscles specifically detect deep pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pacinian corpuscles are specialized mechanoreceptors that detect deep pressure and vibration, playing a crucial role in proprioception and providing sensory feedback about the physical environment.

choices.text: It is called Argyl Robertson pupil.
﻿﻿﻿The vision is normal in right eye.
﻿﻿﻿Seen in optic neuritis, the pupil can paradoxically dilate in the both eyes.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the image given below: (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Seen in optic neuritis, the pupil can paradoxically dilate in the both eyes.

 

The image suggests Marcus Gunn pupil, which is seen in optic neuritis. The right eye is affected, while the left eye is normal.

 

  • ﻿﻿The condition is named after the scientist, Robert Marcus Gunn who belongs to Scotland.

 

Presentation:

 

  • Pupil appears to dilate when light is shone on it (this is also known as a relative afferent pupillary defect or RAPD).
  • The affected pupil constricts less than the unaffected pupil when light is shone on it.
  • The affected pupil may even dilate when light is removed from it (this is known as the Marcus Gunn pupil phenomenon).

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Diagnosed by a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) test, also called swinging flash light test, which involves comparing the pupillary response of the affected eye to that of the unaffected eye when a light is shone on them.
  • In the swinging flashlight test, a light is alternately shone into the left and right eyes. A normal response would be equal constriction of both pupils, regardless of which eye the light is directed at. This indicates an intact direct and consensual pupillary light reflex. When the test is performed in an eye with an afferent pupillary defect, light directed in the affected eye will cause only mild constriction of both pupils (due to decreased response to light from the afferent defect), while light in the unaffected eye will cause a normal constriction of both pupils (due to an intact efferent path, and an intact consensual pupillary reflex). Thus, light shone in the affected eye will produce less pupillary constriction than light shone in the unaffected eye.

 

Management:

 

  • Treatment involves addressing the underlying cause of the afferent pupillary defect, such as optic neuritis or a retinal detachment.
  • In cases where the underlying cause cannot be treated, the patient may need to wear an eye patch to alleviate symptoms caused by the unequal pupillary responses.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is called Argyl Robertson pupil: Incorrect, as Argyl Robertson pupils are associated with neurosyphilis and react to accommodation but not to light.

 

Option B. Both eyes are abnormal: Incorrect, the image specifically shows an abnormal reaction in one eye compared to a normal reaction in the other.

 

Option C. The vision is normal in the right eye: Incorrect as it is not specifically addressed in the image or scenario provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Marcus Gunn pupil, indicative of an RAPD, is a significant sign of optic nerve dysfunction often seen in conditions like optic neuritis. Detecting this early through the swinging flashlight test can guide further diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

choices.text: 4 ml Mgso4 (50% w/v) in 16 ml NS
8 ml MgSo4 (50% w/v) in 12 ml NS
12 ml MgSo4 (50% w/v) in 8 ml NS

questions.text: The loading dose of MgSo4 in pre-eclampsia is? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 8 ml MgSo4 (50% w/v) in 12 ml NS

 

Explanation:

 

The drug of choice for the management of eclampsia is Magnesium Sulfate (MgSO4). The most commonly used regimen in India is the Pritchard regimen, which involves an initial loading dose followed by maintenance doses.

 

For the loading dose, the Pritchard regimen recommends:

 

  • Loading dose: 4 grams of MgSO4 as a 20% solution administered intravenously at 1 gram per minute.
  • Additionally, 10 grams of 50% MgSO4 is administered intramuscularly, with 5 grams in each buttock.

 

In this question, option B, "8 ml MgSO4 (50% w/v) in 12 ml NS," correctly refers to the preparation required to administer the initial dose of MgSO4.

 

The preparation details:

 

  • MgSO4 is available in 50% and 20% concentrations.
  • To make a 50% MgSO4 solution into a 20% solution, a 1.5 times dilution is required.
  • For a 50% MgSO4 solution, 1 ml of the solution contains 0.5 grams of MgSO4 (1 ampoule = 2 ml).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The loading dose of MgSO4 in pre-eclampsia, as per the Pritchard regimen, is 4 grams of MgSO4 as a 20% solution administered intravenously, often prepared using 8 ml of 50% MgSO4 diluted in 12 ml normal saline.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg273, Williams textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 1840

questions.text: Which among the following is the most severe manifestation of CKD? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia 

 

Hyperkalemia, characterized by elevated potassium levels in the blood, is particularly dangerous in CKD due to its direct impact on cardiac function. High potassium levels can disrupt normal heart rhythms, potentially leading to life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased GFR: While it indicates the progression of CKD and reduced kidney function, it does not pose immediate life-threatening risks like hyperkalemia.

 

Option B. Increased creatinine: Indicates kidney dysfunction but is a marker rather than a direct cause of severe clinical consequences.

 

Option D. Proteinuria: Signifies kidney damage; however, it is more of a prognostic indicator rather than an acute life-threatening condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperkalemia in CKD patients is a critical condition that requires immediate medical attention due to its potential to cause fatal cardiac disturbances. Always prioritize the management of hyperkalemia in CKD patients to prevent cardiac complications.

choices.text: Risk of hypotension
Increased risk of liver toxicity
Potential to cause hyperglycemia
Risk of severe muscle cramps

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of hypertriglyceridemia is being considered for niacin therapy to help control her lipid levels. She also has well-controlled type 2 diabetes, managed with metformin and lifestyle modifications. Given her diabetic status, her physician is concerned about potential side effects associated with niacin use. Why should niacin be used with caution in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Potential to cause hyperglycemia

 

Explanation:

 

Niacin therapy, while effective in lowering triglycerides and improving lipid profiles, is associated with a risk of increasing blood glucose levels. Niacin can induce insulin resistance and reduce glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, potentially leading to hyperglycemia. This effect is particularly concerning in patients with diabetes, even those with well-controlled blood sugar levels. Therefore, niacin should be used cautiously in diabetic patients, and their blood glucose should be monitored closely, especially in the initial weeks of therapy to ensure that blood sugar levels remain within a safe range.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Risk of hypotension: Niacin does not typically cause hypotension. It can cause vasodilation and flushing but does not significantly lower blood pressure to a concerning degree, especially not enough to be the primary caution in diabetic patients.

 

B. Increased risk of liver toxicity: Although niacin can cause hepatotoxicity, particularly at high doses, this effect is not specific to diabetic patients and does not directly impact glucose control. Liver function should still be monitored, but it is not the primary concern when considering niacin in a diabetic patient.

 

D. Risk of severe muscle cramps: Muscle cramps are more commonly associated with statin use rather than niacin. Niacin does not directly contribute to myopathy or muscle cramps and thus is not a specific concern in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin can cause an increase in blood sugar levels due to insulin resistance and reduced glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, making its use risky in diabetic patients. Caution and close monitoring of blood glucose levels are necessary when prescribing niacin to individuals with diabetes, particularly those who have well-controlled blood sugar levels, to prevent hyperglycemia and ensure safe therapy.

questions.text: Identify the type of cartilage shown in the image below:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Elastic cartilage

 

  • This image displays a type of cartilage called elastic cartilage.
  • These elastic fibers give the cartilage its unique properties of flexibility and resilience, allowing it to easily return to its original shape after being bent or compressed.
  • On microscopy, elastic cartilage consists of:
    • Chondrocytes within lacunae
    • Elastic fibres in the matrix
    • Perichondrium with outer fibrous layer and the inner cellular layer
  • Function: Maintains the shape of certain structures while allowing great flexibility.
  • Locations: Found in the ear (auricle or pinna), epiglottis, and eustachian tubes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyaline Cartilage: This is the most common type of cartilage. It appears glassy and smooth under the microscope. The extracellular matrix contains a large amount of type II collagen and is filled with chondrocytes, the cells responsible for cartilage synthesis.

 

  • Function: Provides smooth surfaces for movement at joints, flexibility, and support.
  • Locations: Found on joint surfaces, the rib tips, sternum, nose, trachea, and larynx.

 

Option C. Articular Cartilage: A type of hyaline cartilage that covers the surfaces of bones at synovial joints. It has a smooth, slippery surface that decreases friction.

 

  • Function: Enables bones of a synovial joint to slide over each other with minimal friction, distributes load in the joint, and allows for shock absorption.
  • Locations: Covers the ends of bones in all movable joints.

 

Option D. Fibrocartilage: This is a tough, dense, and fibrous material that contains a mix of hyaline cartilage and dense collagen fibers.

 

  • Function: Provides rigidity and shock absorption where it's needed, such as in areas of frequent pressure and pulling.
  • Locations: Found in intervertebral discs, pubic symphysis, menisci of the knee, and the points where tendons attach to bones.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the type of fracture shown in the X-ray of left shoulder? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Neer classification grade 4

 

IMPORTANT CLASSIFICATIONS OF VARIOUS FRACTURES

 

 

NEER CLASSIFICATION OF PROXIMAL HUMERUS FRACTURE

 

  • The classification consists of four major groupings, based on the number of displaced parts.
  • One-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves 1 to 4 parts
    • No or minimal displacement (i.e. <1 cm and <45°)
    • Account for ~70-80% of all proximal humeral fractures and are almost always treated conservatively.

 

 

  • Two-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves 2 to 4 parts
    • One part is displaced (i.e. >1 cm or >45°)
    • Four possible types of two-part fractures are: 
      1. Surgical neck: most common
      2. Greater tuberosity
        • Frequently seen in anterior shoulder dislocation
        • A lower threshold of displacement (>5 mm)
      3. Anatomical neck
      4. Lesser tuberosity: uncommon
    • These fractures account for approximately 20% of proximal humeral fractures.

 

 

  • Three-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves 3 or 4 parts
    • Two parts are displaced (i.e. >1 cm or >45°)
    • 2 three-part fracture patterns are encountered:
      1. Greater tuberosity and shaft are displaced with respect to the lesser tuberosity and articular surface which remain together – most common pattern
      2. Lesser tuberosity and shaft are displaced with respect to the greater tuberosity and articular surface which remain together
    • These fractures account for approximately 5% of proximal humeral fractures.

 

 

  • Four-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves all 4 parts
    • Three parts are displaced (i.e. >1 cm or >45°) with respect to the 4th.
    • These fractures are uncommon (<1% of proximal humeral fractures).
    • This pattern has poor non-operative results as the articular surface is no longer attached to any parts of the humerus. This pattern has a high incidence of osteonecrosis. These fractures require operative management.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ideberg classification grade 4. This system is used to classify the scapular fractures.

 

 

 

Option C. Garden classification grade 3. The Garden classification of subcapital femoral neck fractures is the most widely used. It predicts the development of osteonecrosis.

 

 

 

Option D. Schatzker classification grade 5. This is used to classify tibial plateau fracture.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the grade 4 of the Neer’s classification of the proximal humerus fracture where all the fractured parts of the humerus are displaced.

questions.text: For the action of heparin as an anticoagulant, availability of which of the following chemical substances is mandatory? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Antithrombin-III

 

Heparin acts indirectly by activating Antithrombin-III. The heparin-antithrombin III then binds to the clotting factors of the intrinsic pathway (10, 2, 9 ,11 and 12) and inactivates them. The anticoagulation action is exerted mainly by the inhibition of factor 10 as well as thrombin or factor 2. Therefore Antithrombin-Ill is mandatory for the action of heparin as an anticoagulant. Reduced antithrombin levels can lead to resistance.

 

In true heparin resistance, there is an actual blunting of heparin's anticoagulant effect. This occurs due to:

 

  • Low ATIII levels (most common cause)
  • Increased heparin-binding plasma proteins (acute phase reactants)
  • Increased heparin clearance (e.g., due to splenomegaly in liver disease)

 

Low ATIII levels could be due to decreased synthesis (hereditary, hepatic failure), increased consumption (DIC, MAHA, or in a bypass circuit) or increased loss (nephrotic syndrome).

 

The dose of heparin has to be increased to achieve therapeutic aPTT. Severe antithrombin deficiency may require antithrombin concentrate as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thrombin: Thrombin is a target of the heparin-antithrombin III complex, not a necessary cofactor for heparin's action.

 

Option B. Plasmin: Plasmin is involved in fibrinolysis (the breakdown of clots) and is not directly related to the anticoagulant action of heparin.

 

Option D. Thrombomodulin: Thrombomodulin is a receptor that binds thrombin and is involved in the activation of protein C, which has anticoagulant properties. However, it is not directly required for the action of heparin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The availability of antithrombin-III is mandatory for the anticoagulant action of heparin, as it forms a complex with heparin to inactivate key enzymes in the coagulation cascade.

questions.text: Which of the following caspase binds to Cytochrome C and APAF-1 complex? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Caspase 9  

 

Caspase 9 binds to Cyt-c and APAF-1 complex.

 

Apoptotic stimuli cause the release of cytochrome C into the cytosol. Cytochrome-C binds to a protein called APAF-1 (apoptosis-activating factor-1) to form the apoptosome.

 

This complex then binds caspase-9, resulting in the activation of other caspases.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caspase 1: Involved in the inflammatory response and not in the intrinsic apoptotic pathway.

 

Option B. Caspase 8: Associated with the extrinsic apoptotic pathway, activated by death receptors on the cell surface.

 

Option D. Caspase 4: Involved in the inflammatory response and not directly related to the intrinsic apoptotic pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caspase 9 is the initiator caspase in the intrinsic apoptotic pathway and is activated by binding to the cytochrome C and APAF-1 complex (the apoptosome).

choices.text: Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients
Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma
Early morning spurious diarrhea and tenesmus can occur
Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding rectal carcinoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common variant of rectal carcinoma, accounting for over 95% of cases. This type of cancer originates from the glandular cells lining the rectum. Therefore, stating that adenocarcinoma is a rare variant is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients: This statement is true. Hartmann's operation is a surgical procedure often performed in elderly or debilitated patients with rectal carcinoma. The operation involves resection of the diseased segment of the colon, closure of the remaining rectal stump (forming a "Hartmann's pouch"), and creation of an end colostomy with the proximal colon. It is a suitable option for patients who may not tolerate a more extensive surgical procedure.

 

Option C. Early morning spurious diarrhea and tenesmus can occur: This statement is true. Patients with rectal carcinoma commonly experience symptoms such as diarrhea and tenesmus (a sensation of incomplete evacuation after bowel movements). These symptoms can occur at any time of the day, including early morning, due to the irritation and obstruction caused by the tumor.

 

Option D. Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging: This statement is true. According to the modified Duke's staging system for colorectal cancer, stage A refers to cancer that is confined to the mucosa of the rectum. This early stage indicates that the tumor has not yet penetrated deeper layers or spread beyond the rectum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of rectal carcinoma, accounting for over 95% of cases, making it incorrect to describe it as a rare variant.

questions.text:
